results.title: Clay in a special way (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Larry Schultz, Bill Snider and Oak Creek Films
results.brief_description: The film examines the positive, creative process of an art project with 4th, 5th and 6th grade students, handicapped and non-handicapped. An honest instructor expresses his initial doubts about teaching a “mainstreamed” class. Deaf and blind students participate with the aid of sign language interpreters and sighted students’ oral descriptions. Students are given information on the historical usage of clay through slides and a trip to a local museum. An artist, Maynard Fishler, visits the classroom to discuss his work. Throughout the project, a multi-sensory approach is used. The students decide to interpret transportation with clay, each student developing his own personal communication. The clay sculptures are the visual, concrete expression of a successful learning experience for all. Communication and creativity on may levels are results no less important.

results.title: Clay and water
results.brief_description: In the republic of Mali, in West Africa, traditional architecture is perfectly adapted to climatic conditions and local resources. Houses, monuments and mosques built of clay and earth - some of which have stood for centuries - correspond to the needs of the inhabitants, and show the creative use of materials given to them by nature.

results.title: Clay
results.brief_description: Learn the basic techniques of pottery and ceramics and create objects like vases, piggy banks and pots. Highlights basic techniques such as creating a pinch pot, throwing on a wheel and solid construction as well as the art of glazing.

results.title: Claus Bury, landscape sculpture
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Crafts Council of Australia and Crafts Resource Productions
results.brief_description: This film shows Claus Bury, a German sculptor and jeweller, working with Australian tertiary sculpture students in workshop situations. The film looks in particular at his work in outdoor environments. Music by Geoffrey d’Ombrain and camera and editing by David Corke
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Crafts Council of Australia and Crafts Resource Productions

results.title: Claude Jutra: an unfinished story
results.creator_credit: Paule Baillargeon, Andre Theberge, Anne Frank, National Film Board of Canada, Production Docu 2 and Fox-Fire Films
results.brief_description: Claude Jutra (1930-1986) was an innovative Quebecois filmmaker who made some of Canadian cinema’s best known films including “Mon Oncle Antoine”, “A Chairy tale”, “A Tout prende”, “WOW” and “Kamouraska”. Paule Baillargeon; actress, director and friend; contemplates Jutra’s creative genius, his commitment to furthering French-Candian cultural identity, and his frustrated and difficult career. Through interviews with friends (including Bernardo Bertolucci and Saul Rubinek), film excerpts and extensive footage of the filmmaker himself, Jutra emerges as a sensitive, passionate man who gave his life completely to cinema. Faced with the decline of his faculties due to the onset of Alzheimer’s Disease, he took the decision to end his life aged 56. Some French with English subtitles.

results.title: Classroom crisis: dealing with violence in school (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Dave Bell, Bruce Johnson and Dave Bell Associates
results.brief_description: Violence presents a real danger for teachers. Dr. Fred Feitler of Youngstown State University has developed strategies for dealing with student fights, physical assaults, disciplinary confrontations and other crisis situations.
